topics.body:
For those interested: apparently over the past 25 years the number of people living in mega-cities has tripled; so yeah the theory that in the future that the majority of people will be living in megacities is a fairly accurate theory, except it's probably going to happen over the next 3 decades not 100 years.

Also IBM has managed to create a chip that the transistors are almost atom sized; that was five years ahead of projections.

topics.body:
"@toxicrystal":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a00bb76368723175001c4f#post_55a00bb76368723175001c4f
That's what quantum computing is.

Quantum computing is right now only capable of being done in lab settings cause the chips have to be super cooled, but once they're able to do it in room temperature that's going to be really cool.  Quantum computing is *REALLY* good at crunching lots and lots of numbers incredibly fast.


There's also using light instead of electricity for traditional computer chips, which is already going to be used commercially for supercomputers in less than three years; that is good cause that sort of chip is ten times faster than traditional computer chips.


Computer chips that simulate brain cells, for brevity's sake people just call them neurochips even though that isn't a accurate name, are good at logical breakdowns.


Computer chips that use light are good at being fast.
Quantum computers are good at intensive calculations.
"Neurochips" are good at logic.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
